page.title: 18TUCKERS' ARMS, DALWOOD.
page.content: The Tuckers Arms is a very old pub. There is a skittle alley and a garden with wooden tables .The pub may be as many as 640 years old.Men are thought to have lodged in the pub when building the church.The Tuckers Arms has a thatched roof and the building is stone and cob with old wooden beams .Inside there is a flagstone floor and an inglenook fireplace. There is a public bar and a lounge bar. The Inn is kept by Mr and Mrs Oakins .On Fair Day there are stalls outside the pub. In May the school children do Maypole dancing on the forecourt. At one time there were seven ale houses in Dalwood, some of them being only one room of a farm house where ale or cider could be obtained. The Tuckers' Arms is now the only inn in Dalwood.
